Yes everything is correct whatever you said Melanie, We have jobs in downstream CI which will be merging soon that deploy with force_config_drive= true and vfat/iso9660 driver type. This one  we want to have it upstream so that we can cover the testcase as melanie mention using explicit restapi call with config_drive=true for force_config_drive=false env. 

I am not completely sure about this point that if nova.conf.force_config_Drive=false then tempest.conf.compute_feature_enabled.config_drive=false will have false value . I know that user can mention it at the time of deployment by setting these param:

ir_tripleo_overcloud_deploy_override_options: |-
                      --config-heat ComputeExtraConfig.nova::compute::force_config_drive='false' 
and
ir_tempest_run_override_options: "--config-options compute-feature-enabled.config_drive='false' \
 
(Note: By default the openstack deployment is done with force_config_drive=false)

Not many people know this (including me, at first!) but as a user you can actually request config drive from the nova REST API:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=create-server-detail#id12

Now, in an environment where the nova.conf has [DEFAULT]/force_config_drive = True, this would be a no-op. BUT, in an environment with [DEFAULT]/force_config_drive = False, the user can get a config drive by calling POST /servers with config_drive: True.

The confusing bit is that tempest seems to use CONF.compute_feature_enabled.config_drive == NOVA_CONF.force_config_drive. This means that tempest sets CONF.compute_feature_enabled.config_drive = True when nova.conf force_config_drive = True. This is the no-op situation for the config_drive REST API parameter. In this configuration, test_live_block_migration_with_config_drive would be 100% duplicated with test_live_block_migration, which would take additional gate testing time and resources for no gain.

What we want in this patch is to be able to get a config drive when nova.conf force_config_drive = False. My thinking is that when force_config_drive = False, then tempest compute_feature_enabled.config_drive = False, most likely.

Downstream, we have deployments where nova.conf force_config_drive = False and we want to be able to test when the user passes config_drive: True to the nova REST API in our tempest.

What do you think? Do you think this patch makes sense as-is? Or do you think it would be better to just have the duplicated test coverage in the gate by doing skipUnless(CONF.compute_feature_enabled.config_drive) on test_live_block_migration_with_config_drive? Or is there another option I'm not thinking of?

> My point was that we have no tempest suite upstream for live
 > migration with FORCE_CONFIG_DRIVE=False. So adding this to tempest
 > will not result in covering it.

*we have no live migration deployment with FORCE_CONFIG_DRIVE=False

It seems like we are stuck not being able to cover both scenarios because we can't represent two different configurations in a single job (nova-live-migration).

[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1cd5563f2dd2b218db2422397c8aab394d484626/playbooks/legacy/nova-live-migration/run.yaml#L34

Yes in either case we need two deployment to cover both scenario 
1. Use rest api to cover config drive migration(FORCE_CONFIG_DRIVE=false)
2. use FORCE_CONFIG_DRIVE=true to cover all the migration with config drive

But with current tempest suite with FORCE_CONFIG_DRIVE=false deployment we are not even touching config drive enabled live migration which is the reason we suggested this case to at-least someway we can fill the gap.

white_list items from saved_state are exempt from anything black_list does. Which reminds me that I should probably add a warning in the case where the blacklisted id is present in the saved_state...

so looking at this again, if a resource is present after init_saved_state was called, it could also mean someone else on the cloud is running tests or creating resources after that snapshot was taken.
there could be any number of reasons for it to exist outside of both lists. This function just alerts the user that they are present and unaccounted for.
why do we print the warning only if it's a dry_run?

The primary purpose of using --black_list is to delete specified resources, not to alert the user of resource leaks. The purpose of dry-run is to alert the user of what will happen if they run the cleanup command. So I thought if an alert were to be given, it would be best given during a dry-run.

It seems more future-proof to me to put it in the base class along with the setup of all the other clients.  The only reason I can think of for not doing this is if setting up admin credentials is somehow too expensive to be done for all scenarios, but that seems very unlikely.  Can you confirm either way?

> Oh, sorry, I missed the discussion. But I think we don't need to expose the admin credential to all subsidiaries at this point unless they need it.

Thanks but I'm still missing an answer to the question "why should we *not* expose the admin credential?"

So far noone has said that it is expensive (e.g. it makes the tests slower, or consumes too much extra RAM).  E.g. does it cause extra API calls or require extra resources?

OTOH I already stated the advantage of exposing it in the base class: this new SEV scenario needs it, and probably others will in the future, so we can avoid extra effort for test writers later on by sharing it now in the base class.

So far that is one advantage and zero disadvantages.  If I'm missing something then please let me know.

> And, if we add admin client to another scenario, we can refactor the code. I think your assumption might be true but I also think it's a kind of refactoring and it should be separated if it can make a patch smaller.

Only 4 lines smaller.  I could separate it but then would I put it before or after the SEV commit?  If I put it after then there is no saving and actually there is more work, because I would have to add the admin credentials to the SEV commit and then immediately move them in the next commit.  If I put it before then it might get rejected due to the lack of clarity explained above, and then I would have to rebase the SEV commit.  I am happy to do that if it is not likely to get rejected, but it seems like a lot of extra complication and I'm not sure there would be much benefit.

+1
Why don't we take that way?

It not just reads it might try to interpret it, what grantees we do not have random content there at this time ? Isn't this command might fail in case it finds something meaningless for ex. partition outside geometry.

 dd if=/dev/<mydev> of=/tmp/test bs=4k count=1 # also reads , the /tmp/file size is check-able.

Checking that it can be read on both sides doesn't really tell us that it's the same volume, or that writes got flushed and are visible to the other side, etc.

I would assume we should write something to the device and verify that it is sane on the other end. We could do that with mount, if mkfs is on the cirros image, but it would be trivial to just do this with dd:

 echo "foo" | dd of=/dev/sdX bs=1

..

 dd if=/dev/sdX count=3 bs=1

This is the previous way of checking whether volume is connected or not, and I wonder why you don't use this way in your testcase?
Maybe to read disks of a server is more safe than to read the partition table?

This check works OK when you attach a disk for the first time. It verifies that the newly attached disk has been seen by the vm (eg VM1). 

The problem with this check, particularly for multi-attach, is that if you detach a multi-attached disk from a different vm (eg VM2), you need to check that the disk is still actually connected to VM1. 

If you mistakenly drop the volume connection (a bug) on the host from VM1, VM1 will still think it's connected and get_disks() will return the disk as if it were attached (Related-Bug: 1752115). You have to force VM1 to try to access the disk to see this particular failure scenario. 

In general, this is a better check than get_disks() as it checks not only that the disk is seen by the VM, but that it is also read-able.

The test logic itself is fine, though we can add the cold migrate case as well for completeness. It's more of a style thing that we have a method that purports to verify inventory, and oh btw lemme just delete the server too.

I know in the other review I argued for not copy-pasting code, but I think in this case it wouldn't be so bad if we explicitly:

1. get the VGPU inventories before the test (you already do this)
2. after the test, explicitly delete the server
3. get the VGPU inventories after the test
4. assert inventories from step 1 and 3 are the same.

2, 3 and 4 are currently done inline by this method, and I don't think it'd be a bad idea to have 2 and 3 in the test method themselves as separate steps, and have 4 be this method converted into a assert_vgpu_inventories_equal() or something, that gets passed the inventories from 1 and 3 by the main test method.

#1) Update the method name so its more specific and this allow testing inventory after the basic smoke test as well as migration.
#2) Instead of deleting monitor the inventory of the source host before and after migration and confirm inventory increases accordingly after the guest lands on the source.  The tradeoff is inventory checks can only be done around migration/resize tests and not basic vgpu creation.

This check enforces that tokens that can be provided via 'Authorization: Bearer' only be tokens obtained through an application credential. I don't feel strongly (pro or against) that this check should be here, but if we removed it, then tokens obtained via other methods could also be passed in a OAuth 2.0 compliant manner via the Authorization header. This decouples the authentication bit to obtain the token with the how the token is sent over to the services and verified. There is nothing particularly different between these tokens.

neutron/services/revisions/revision_plug.message:
I would like to have a conversation as to whether this approach is too intrusive in the guts of the revisions plugin. Maybe it is also very complicated and there is a simpler and safer approach. I played a little bit with the unit test cases that you added in this patch, while leaving the revision plugin unmodified. Tracing the execution of a subnet description update this is what happens in sequence:

1) The db plugin calls the IPAM to update the subnet object:  https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L968-L969

2) The IPAM calls the OVO update method: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/ipam_backend_mixin.py#L219

3) The OVO update method  https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/objects/base.py#L939-L943 receives the following as the fields to be updated:

(Pdb) updates
{'ipv6_ra_mode': None, 'subnetpool_id': None, 'cidr': AuthenticIPNetwork('10.0.0.0/24'), 'ip_version': 4, 'segment_id': None, 'ipv6_address_mode': None, 'description': 'Test Description'}

The return of obj_db_api.update_object triggers the execution of the bump_revisions method in the revision plugin with the following in session.dirty:

(Pdb) session.dirty
IdentitySet([<neutron_lib.db.standard_attr.StandardAttribute[object at 7f165a2c41f0] {id=8, resource_type='subnets', description='Test Description', revision_number=0, created_at=datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 3, 0, 12, 23), updated_at=None}>, <neutron.db.models_v2.Subnet[object at 7f165a298d30] {project_id='bea7b7b5-aeaa-4282-a093-62e91ea569ae', id='69d0985e-d8f6-4f69-9a7b-e395c49c3b19', in_use=False, name='', network_id='681f8697-4f61-48e0-958b-998ae4aae58d', segment_id=None, subnetpool_id=None, ip_version=4, cidr='10.0.0.0/24', gateway_ip='10.0.0.1', enable_dhcp=True, ipv6_ra_mode=None, ipv6_address_mode=None, standard_attr_id=8}>])

As you can see, there are two dirty objects, one of type StandardAttribute and the other of type Subnet, which is also of type HasStandardAttributes. I think this is because the code is asking the DB to update fields in the Subnet object, not only the description in StandardAttribute

In the case of networks, the DB plugin updates directly the DB (no OVO) here: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L472-L473. The updates are:

(Pdb) (n)
{'description': 'Test Description'}

When the network.update statement finishes, the execution of the bump_revisions method in the revision plugin is triggered with the following in session.dirty:

(Pdb) session.dirty
IdentitySet([<neutron_lib.db.standard_attr.StandardAttribute[object at 7f3beebdfc70] {id=6, resource_type='networks', description='Test Description', revision_number=1, created_at=datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 3, 0, 28, 52), updated_at=datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 3, 0, 28, 53)}>])

And that is why we fail to bump the revision number.

Wouldn't it be easier to include in the network update one of the fields in the network (without really changing it) to force is in session.dirty? And we can do the same for routers. I didn't have time tonight to test this approach

The only reason why I would like to have it fixed in the revision_plugin directly it that it would be done for all resources which have description field from the StandardAttributes class.
Otherwise we will need to remember to call bump_revision() for every such resource which is IMHO error prone.

In fact, why not use the bump_revision() method:

https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/db/standard_attr.py#L200

One example is here:

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/l3_db.py#L610

on a related note i also need to file a bug and add a ptg item related to libvirts current behaivor.
this is needed for vdpa because of a behavior in libvirt we were not previouly aware of.
even without asking libvirt sets RLIMIT_MEMLOCK to guest ram + 1G when a vm has VFIO, mdev or nvme devices assigned. qemu then locks all the guest ram and the deivce dma buffers and caches.
that means all instance using neutron sriov ports, pci passthough, vGPU and cinder NVMEoF volumns today are effectivly locked. meaning our memoy over subsciption is broken in those cases.

i need to add this for vdpa because libvirt currently do not do that for vdpa yet but it likely will in the future to be consitent with other device types.

im not really sure how to fix our memory over allocation support in nova.
i only became aware of this last week and confirm it on wednesday.
http://paste.openstack.org/show/803381/

the drastic approch is to require all vms with passthough devices to use hugepages or hw:mem_page_size in genral
even with small pages to prevent memory over allocation.
less drastic would be to set memtune.hard_limit equal to RAM+1G as libvirt does and claim ram+1G in placment
if we did this we would want to make the hard_limit configurable by the flavor because libvirt is just gussing 1G is enough today its very possible to exceed that.
we discuss this at some lenght in the SEV spec and determined that we cant come up with a resonable algorithm to determin the hard_limit.
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/641994/2/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.rst#167

when we use locked today we dont set hard_limit so RLIMIT_MEMLOCK shoudl be set to unlimited.
i dont think adding the ablity to created locked vms makes our currnt issue any worse so i would like to add the extra spec for now and then figure out what to do in general later.

i can explay it anything truthy i guess i just would prefer if peopel stuck to true|false|True|False and ingored the rest.

well we dont require hw:mem_page_size for realtime or for sev but both enable locked today but neither require hw:mem_page_size set. so that is why i was not going to requrie that.

i can but then we likely shoudl be requireing it for the other case too.

we need to talk about memory locking in general some other time so if we want to be conservative and require hw:mem_pages_and require all instance that have lock memory to be numa instances.

oslo_cache/_memcache_pool.py.message: Do we also need to set deserializer?

No I don't think we need to do the same thing for deserializer here.

On pymemcache only serializer [1][2] take care of the pickle version, so this is why I only mapped `serializer` with `pickleProtocol`, and anyway if no deserializer is given then it will be automatically set at line 253.

Thoughts?


[1] https://github.com/pinterest/pymemcache/blob/master/pymemcache/serde.py#L43
[2] https://github.com/pinterest/pymemcache/blob/master/pymemcache/serde.py#L82
I assume all of these have no meaning in pymemcache?

Looks like it doesn't like this:

https://2e2758d1408492f410e7-6319048316c626def25c176077b7ea65.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/711227/4/check/kolla-ansible-centos8-source/4448393/primary/logs/kolla/keystone/keystone.txt

The libraries really handle connections differently, I was able to fix some parts of this locally, but I wittnessed lot of differences between the two libraries on dead hosts where pymemcache drop automatically dead host and python-memcached not, but the main issue behind this behavior is that on oslo.cache we don't want to drop conn.clients to continue even if host are dead.

I suppose we want to delegate dead host management to failover mechanismes like pacemaker by example and oslo.cache memcached servers's management is based on simple retrying while host will re-become up.

Another point is that on python-memcached connection's properties like `deaduntil` etc... are public, and on pymemcache these elements are not public, so to obtain similar results here we should tweak private/protected properties not exposed by the pymemcache API, which is something that I really prefer to avoid.

IMO The benefits behind switching from one library to another are too low compared to the possible side effects we risk to face, I think we should give priority to stability, in other words since the side effects behind these changes are to high it could be a wise decision to restore the python-memcached based backend.

I prefer to do more tests during 1 or 2 days before abandoning definitely these changes.

If the scheduling is done correctly, no incorrect vnic type should be passed here.

what Brent wrote is correct but we may need to add debug logging like is done in 
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/7c1e21a3f35e80e176dfc025eb6f4a0024cb137c/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/mech_agent.py#L91-L94

Both OVS and the SR-IOV mechanism drivers support 'direct' ports, the former for Openvswitch SR-IOV offload and the latter for standard old PCI passthrough. The distinguishing detail is the presence of 'switchdev' in the capabilities of the binding profile - with the intention that the sriovnicswitch mechanism driver not bind ports with the switchdev capability. As I understand it, if a mechanism driver does not support the port binding it simply returns from bind_port without calling set_binding. I do not think throwing an exception from the bind_port method as outlined in neutron_lib.plugins.ml2.api is appropriate in this case.

IIUC we dropped this everywhere else, so can be dropped here, too.
I don't think tenant_id should need to appear here, either.
I'm not sure about this, maybe a question to other OSC cores: Wouldn't it be better to make all required arguments positional?

I was thinking about this idea quite long already. There are many cases where too many required params are required. Converting them all to positional will very quickly become a mess, therefore mostly as positionals we try to keep ID (of parent) and max name. There surely are further deviation from that statement, but that is my dicrection.
can we drop "router" here? that sounds confusing to me.
Looking at this again, I think this option should be named "--ip-address" in order to be more in line with other commands and with the parameter name in the API.

I had to check in the implementation to understand what this option actually does. Maybe change the wording to make it more explicit, like:

The IPv6 address that is to be proxied. In case the port has multiple addresses assigned, use this option to select which address is to be used.
API describes it this way: "The IPv6 address which the ndp proxy annunciate to external network." While it apparently has syntactical issue, this look like a short and relatively clear description.

Maybe prefer the wording that e.g. "network delete" uses:

NDP proxy(s) to delete (name or ID)

Or maybe even "NDP proxy/proxies". Would need a native speaker to judge which looks better to them.

I would suggest to copy the wording from e.g. "port list" here, too:

List only NDP proxies associated to this router (name or ID)
This should also be "--ip-address" like for create.
same comment about the wording as for the other options. As the port can have multiple addresses, the text should rather refer to the proxies IP address, too.
Comparing with "port list" I think it should also be possible to list proxies by name and filtered by project.
Is it possible to update the name of a proxy, too? If yes, that option should be added here.

nit: you don't need this since we only support Python 3

  super().setUp()

would be sufficient. Here and elsewhere

I have a feeling these should be the other way around? The NDP proxy is a subresource of a router resource, yes? If so, the parent should go first:

  openstack router ndp proxy create $ROUTER $NAME

Alternatively, is 'name' required? If not, perhaps this should be an optional argument?

  openstack router ndp proxy create --name $NAME ... $ROUTER

According to the API ref the name is indeed optional, so it shouldn't be required here.

In hindsight, it possibly should have been made an actual subresource of a router, but I even in the current version, it certainly is attached to the router more than to the port, since the implementation is happening in the l3-agent.

So all in all, I think the latter variant is what I would support.
So this is using the SDK. This is important later in the test...

Actually it should be "... fixed-ip values or NDP proxy settings." but maybe that is overdoing it. Or make a new "if" block specifically for NDP proxy? I think I'd prefer the latter. There is a dedicated block for qos_policy already.

Also like for qos, you need to check whether the router already has an external gateway set. If that is the case, you can still update the NDP proxy setting without the "--external-gateway" option being present in the update command.

But doing "router create router --enable-ndp-proxy" without an external gateway will fail:

ConflictException: 409: Client Error for url: https://192.168.34.20:9696/networking/v2.0/routers, Can not enable ndp proxy on router cc50f91f-4c5b-4d82-924e-bd3705abbd03, The request body not contain external gateway information.

The idea is to check that condition already in the client and not send the failing request to the API.

Thanks, very carefulness!!! This is timeworn code's remains. At fist, the "enable_ndp_proxy" locate in router's "external_gateway". But now, it locate in router directly. So, we just need delete "or NDP proxy", don't need extra if block.

Instead of doing things this way, you can use a common variable and store that. For example:

  ndp_proxy_group.add_argument(
      '--enable-ndp-proxy',
      dest='enable_ndp_proxy',
      default=None,
      action='store_true',
      help=_("Enable IPv6 NDP proxy on external gateway"),
  )
  ndp_proxy_group.add_argument(
      '--disable-ndp-proxy',
      dest='enable_ndp_proxy',
      default=None,
      action='store_false',
      help=_("Disable IPv6 NDP proxy on external gateway"),
  )
Done

setup.cfg.message:
Why are these called

  network ndp proxy

and not simply

  ndp proxy

or even

  router ndp proxy

They're not attributes of a network, right?

Looking back, I see you originally called this 'router ndp proxy' in PS1, changed this to 'ndp proxy' in PS2, and settled on this in PS3. If there was a good reason for this then it would be helpful to include that information in the commit message.

It seems that this matches what was done for other recent Neutron additions, like "network qos" or "network rbac". However, since in the API ref the feature is listed as "Router NDP proxy" https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html?expanded=create-ndp-proxy-detail#router-ndp-proxy-ndp-proxies , I actually agree that "router ndp proxy" would seem to fit best.

If there is a reason to go with "network ndp *" instead, this block would need to be moved upwards to keep alphabetic ordering.

The 'ndp proxy' is a network feature. I am inspired by "network agent xx", " network flavor xx", you can find similar command by execute "openstack --help|grep network". Myabe it can be designed as "network l3 ndp proxy xxx", just like " network l3 conntrack helper xxx"

Unfortunately network can refer to two things here, the network service (i.e. neutron) and the network resource (i.e. an instance of a neutron network). In the two examples you gave, both refer to the network service and they are necessary to distinguish from e.g. compute agents and compute flavors. However, I don't think that's necessary here since NDP proxies don't make sense in any other context. It's also not a network subresource so we don't want to do that.

'router ndp proxy' is probably the best option here, I think?

nova/compute/pci_placement_translator.py.message: it just occurred to me that this is modelling both the resource provider and the inventory
Yes, anything that can be updated back to placement via the provider_tree interface

we may want to relax this in the future to allow some VFs to be consumed as VFs and some as VDPA devices. but since that needs VF/vdpa devices to be supported in a neutron context its out of scope for this spec.

eventually we might need to consider allowing that and if we do we may need to break out groups of VFs into Child RPs so they can have different traits too.

I know intel QAT device have at least 3 different offload engine that can be consumed seleperatly but you consume them via a single type of VF that has access to all the offload types. so I don't currently know of any hadware that really supports multiple types of VF from the same pf right now.
I agree that if we need mixed VF config within the same PF then we need to model the VFs as RPs under the PF.

i'm not seeing how this would be used with the composable roles approach from the t-h-t patch. It would prepare both images, but the generated output wouldn't be correct.

I still think it might be good to lay out an end to end proposal on how this would work. One question I have with the composable roles approach is if the default would be to assume nodes have been upgraded to 9, or that they have remained on 8.

This isn't very upstream friendly of me. But I have outlined the process for each proposal on this issue:
https://issues.redhat.com/browse/OSP-16045

I'll paste the contents of my final comment here for everyone:

So, there are two options we are discussing for this. I'll highlight the process behind both solutions here for clarity:

A. As proposed by my patches here:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/850131
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/848208
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/848960
The process for this would be:

1. User edits the ContainerImagePrepare parameter to include the `namespaces` list:
namespaces: ['registry.redhat.io/rhosp-rhel8', 'registry.redhat.io/rhosp-rhel9'] 

2. User performs the undercloud upgrade as usual.

3. During the overcloud upgrade, the user identifies the nodes they would like to 
STAY on RHEL8. They then use the `–limit` option to avoid performing the OS LEAP upgrade during the FFU for those nodes identified.

4. During the update run, we will leverage the new dictionary parameter via the patches proposed above to render the docker_config on each node with OS specific images.

B. The alternate proposal is to leverage the composable roles mechanism, with some initial proposals from Takashi:
https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:role-image-prepare

For this, we would still need to implement a mechanism within tripleo-common. 
Something that is able to leverage the role specific params suggested by Takashi, as currently we are only looking for a single CIP param:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/master/tripleo_common/image/kolla_builder.py#L175

With the idea being that we would:
1. Have the user edit the ContainerImagePrepare file to add the new role based CIP params.

2. Upgrade the undercloud as usual 

3. Implement a mechanism to leverage stack exports and move nodes that will remain on RHEL8 over to their own composable role.

4. Include the new CIP file in the deployment, and continue with the FFU as usual.


In both cases, the assumption would be that all nodes will default to RHEL9 unless explicitly excluded from the LEAP upgrade step. We would also assume that this is an edge case and not all users will need or want this feature. So unless the required arguments are provided, we would only have the RHEL9 images.

Forgive me if this was discussed but why are we hardcoding versions here? Will we need to touch this code every time we need to support next set of RHEL versions? Can the '8' and '9' be something that gets passed in?

Yeah, so the reason for this is because of how we reference the key with ansible. We utilise ansible_fact['distribution_major_version']

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/848208/23/deployment/ovn/ovn-controller-container-puppet.yaml#372

We can indeed do something like 'legacy' 'latest'. But then we need additional logic to determine which one we're using within Ansible. It wouldn't be as simple as using the ansible fact to pick the key from this dictionary. 

But, in saying that. Maybe we would prefer to have the additional logic checks rather than hardcoded keys like this. I think in either case, we will need to at least check for '8' somewhere. 

I would also like to avoid having additional Ansible tasks with conditionals. Each skipped task still takes time. There's n containers that need this to happen, so we would be increasing the deployment time by skipping for each container that requires the check. I'm trying to avoid causing an increased deployment time as part of this change.

I think it's important to codify the use of ansible_fact['distribution_major_version'] as the multi-os key. That would help reviewers understand why we're using '8' and '9' and not abstract terms like old/new or previous/current.

One possibility for this code (THT would be another matter) is to define abstract names in tripleo_common.constants:
  
MULTI_OS_VERSION_OLD = '8'
MULTI_OS_VERSION_NEW = '9'

That said, it would be really (REALLY) good to minimize the places across all tripleo projects where these hard-coded references appear. One can only imagine the chaos that would occur when we update things in the future, and we miss one.

For the multi-os use case, do we need to support different combinations of secure vs insecure hosts on a per-os basis?

- If yes, then you need to test whether you need to insecure.add each host *inside* to iteration loop.
- If no, then you only need to test the first dict key (i.e. the first os).

I think the expectation will be that we're pulling / pushing all of these containers from the same container registry. Not sure what the use case would be for having multiple registries, so we should either be all insecure or secure.

We just needed to add in the extra code here to iterate the new dictionary values and handle them the same way we have been handling the others.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: on exception, the fallocate precheck will also be skipped.  Is there an alternative efficient method to determine the filesize in Debian ?
On Debian though, would this st_size check and fallocate now always be skipped ? (what is "not a supported operation on Debian"?)

This change is not OS dependent. The size check and fallocate skip are only applied to the signature file on both CentOS and Debian.

On Centos, the signature file object type is cStringio.StringO. This object type does not have fileno() attribute so the size check and fallocate are skipped.

On Debian, the signature file object type is _io.BytesIO. This object type has fileno() attribute as it inherits from IOBase object. But this object is not backed by an actual file so it doesn't have the file descriptor and the exception is UnsupportedOperation. This is why I said "not a supported operation on Debian".

On the other hand, the iso file size is checked on both Centos and Debian.

The behaviour of this if code block is consistent, and it is to make sure only the iso file size is checked and allocated(fallocate) accordingly. 
If the file_size is set to -1, it means it is the signature file that only has less than 1 kb, and the file size check is not required. 
Therefore, skipping the fallocate precheck for the signature file is intended.
This will also be blocked to proceed with the following checks on Debian?
This is blocked only if it is the signature file. See the explanation above.

thanks Shawn for the clarification; I see this is determining to perform further checks and reservations (i.e with fallocate) whether it's a signature file or not.

tasks/update/disable_fencing.yaml.message:
'ignore_errors: true' is very bad practise because it causes a big red error to show up in the stdout and displays it like a failed task.

A better practise is to use 'failed_when' with a conditional to determine when the task is considered a known fail. https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_error_handling.html#defining-failure

You could even use something like this given that this is purely fact gathering:

  changed_when: false
  failed_when: false

That way the task never shows as changed, or as failed. It also never shows as a failed result and the output is all green.
Ack..We are Jjust fetching the output and not changing anything on target host.

ie:

This is a nice small change. I think a future cleanup refactor would be to tease apart the manager responsibilities vs. the API. Probably the calling of plugins should move to a "PluginManager" instead of "ManagerService". The Manager and the API can then both use the PluginManager to perform w/e DB operations or plugin resource modifications. There will still be a bit of tension where the Manager and API components will be using different areas of the plugin's interface. I think that's something we can also tease apart over time though.
I raised my concerns in the related spec: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/blazar-specs/+/809485
Overall I am concerned that we are moving complex functions to run inside the API process. Maybe API should run only read operations? (get/list)

Ditto
Ditto.
In my view (and see also the next comment), the plugins would (well, at least should) live at the level of Blazar Manager and be accessible via RPC, not the other way around.

It's not wrong that the RPC interface from API to manager looks like it does. I also don't see why it would be affecting the plugins per se. I mean, it should be extended / made more flexible to accommodate the variance but otherwise no need to remove it. The Blazar API translates REST API for end users to internal Blazar calls (the Blazar Manager RPC). It's a valid role, I would leave it be.
implementation
Does the interface need to expose this? In the current plugins, things are deallocated just in `on_end`.

Currently, before blazar allocates, it gets allocation candidates, and passes these to enforcement, which suggests we need something like this for third party plugins as well. Additionally, we may want allocation candidates in the interface, as it allows an early exit, in the case that one of the reservations is invalid. ``allocate()`` may be an expensive operation, and it should be delayed until blazar is is sure all reservations can be made successfully.
We need additional functions to validate create and update parameters.
It might be useful to have per-plugin configuration of the delay.
I like this.
I like this too.
Another point is that both the API and manager will need access to the plugins. Should they be extracted into an agent of their own?
We can also discuss another alternative: make all resources fit into shared database tables, by storing their unique schema values as a JSON dictionary.

If it is unlikely that Blazar will ever need to query on this data, i.e., it is conceived to be opaque, then it should be a better approach for extension as we don't risk over-abstracting and can proceed more organically.
I agree strong core is important.
I can't quite parse this sentence.

They propose to merge a set of tables, '<something>_whatever' into 'whatever' with all the existing columns plus a column to store '<something>'. This may impact the performance as it's no longer that cheap to differentiate '<something>'s. Unless we go with the "unify everything and use JSON to store extra metadata", I disagree it's the right approach for this spec.
Plus the /resources API endpoint.

Has the RPC impact on performance been measured? For clean architecture's sake, I would keep the RPC if it's not really a bottleneck. Most sensitive ops should be internal to Blazar Manager and its coordination anyway.

No, this is a python anti-pattern:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26320899/why-is-the-empty-dictionary-a-dangerous-default-value-in-python

You should never use a mutable object as a default parameter for a method because if it gets modified, the default changes.

tox.ini.message: or just don't use asserts in production code 😇

Yeah. I tend to agree with Sean here. I would like to use assert for preconditions that should not (even could not) happen in production but can happen in badly set up unit or functional test. But this does not worth to block the vdpa series. We can take this outside :)

asserts exist separately form exceptions explicitly so that they can be optimized out at runtime.

we discussed this on irc im going to move this to passevn so that we can disable it if we want to on the command line when running tests locally.

openstackclient/network/v2/network.py.message:
> pep8: F821 undefined name 'parse'

Please fix pep8 errors, as I see this error is causing the failure of unit tests also.

to be consequent with other boolean options this should be a pair: cascade and no-cascade.

For example see the ListNetwork and --external and --internal how to solve it. You need a mutually_exclusive_group for it to avoid such situation when somebody added both --cascade and --no-cascade.

You have to take care of these in take_action_network method, see https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/src/branch/master/openstackclient/network/v2/network.py#L549-L554
